description.text:
I have an old vintage Soviet robot toy. It's dated from the 80's and has "Made in USSR" stamp on it.
Mr. Roboto had it's "ear plugs" missing and I saw a great opportunity to use 3D printer to fix it. He is really happy now!
Design by Mold Busters https://www.bustmold.com/locations/ottawal/

Tested on Replicator 2.
Works perfectly at basic settings:
Quality: Medium
Infill: 10%
Number of Shells: 2
Layer height: 0.27
Please send your build comments.

description.text: I liked some of the other Tie hangers but I wanted multiple places and need it to fit over a larger closet rod.
2 place hanger for belts.
Scalextric road barrier left high
This hook works with the Ikea Expedit line of shelving. It hooks at the back of a shelf providing a hook for a wire or string. We used them to hang stockings
Nothing fancy, made in Sketchup. Simple Bracket that grips around two of the antennas and supports from underneath. ABS at 20% fill works well for me, but flexes slightly.

Print with good amount of fill to avoid making it too flimsy.
Prints in two parts, to mount on the wall about 50mm apart. Try it on your router and measure the gap to be sure.
After mounting the brackets on the wall, unscrew the left/right antennas and reattach them through the hole of the bracket. Let the bottom L part of the bracket hold the router body from underneath.

description.text:
Here's my modular drawer for small things like electronics components, nuts and bolt and just general small things.
The tolerances are pretty tight so make sure your printer is well calibrated and extruding at the correct thickness.
It's printed in PLA with 20% infill.
Each module measures 56 x 46 x 100mm.
I haven't made a separator yet but will soon.
Enjoy!
:)

Update 6/11/2014
Added a couple of larger modules to accommodate larger objects and also made the draws walls slightly thicker, (only half a mil but should make them a bit more rigid)
I haven't actually printed the new parts out yet but once I do I'll post some more pic.
The dimensions of the larger modules are 84 x 46 x 100mm.

description.text:
I would like to thank every single one of you for helping me in achieving 10,000 downloads, as a gift to all of you I am releasing the dual extruder version of the diamond lamp. There are two versions : one with the bottom sculpted like all the sides, the other one with a full bottom. Read the article by Tailor3d : https://tailor3d.wordpress.com/2015/05/29/minecraft-and-3d-printing-were-made-for-each-other/
Read the article by 3dprint.com : http://3dprint.com/98696/3d-print-minecraft-nightlight/
Check out my redstone version : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:526104 To transform this piece of plastic into an awesome lamp check out the post-printing section Thanks to Tailor3d (thumbnail), matt448 (video), MrFox (instructable) for their awesome makes.
Special thanks to jrokusekj who helped me debug the files and who was the first to print it. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3vDpqHp6_fw

Doesn't Matter

Yes

author: soldanr

description.text:
This is a case for the Duet 3d printer controller.
BOM
15mm nylon spacers (This allows space under the PCB for wires)
4x M3 screws to secure PCB
2 screws to secure the case
100 x 123 x 3mm acrylic sheet
Using acrylic lowers the print time and gives a really nice finish.
I just glued it to the inside of the case (see pics)
20% infill printed in PLA.
I used the screw terminals on the PCB so made the case slightly bigger than the board itself.

description.text:
This is a filament guide which can be mounted near the extruder to reduce friction of the filament when entering the extruder to a minimum. It uses two 608er ball bearings and can be mounted with two M4 screws. Don't tighten them too hard (like I did as you can see).
Printed and used for my Multec Multirap M420.
I've printed this with 0,2 mm layer height, worked perfectly. When the bearing seats are too tight grind them down a bit.
Turns out these guys work better with only two magnets. Also watch out for air friction giving you false negative results, folks.

title: Eggbot coordinate demo plot (v2.1.0 and later)

description.text:
Use this SVG file to better understand how your drawing in Inkbot gets laid down as ink by the Eggbot on your eggs, light bulbs, or other drawing media.
This drawing is intended for use with v2.1.0 and later of the Eggbot Control extension.  For prior versions of that extension, see Thing 4419.

• Open this SVG file in Inkscape
  • Open the Eggbot Control extension (Extensions > EggBot > Eggbot Control ...)
  • Ensure that you are running v2.1.0 or later of the Eggbot Control extension by selecting the "*" tab.
  • In the Options tab of the Eggbot Control extension, ensure that the "Start with pen centered" option is checked
  • Click the "Apply" button to save the setting from 3 above
  • Position your pen over your egg where you want the midline (y=500) of the Inkscape plot to be
  • In the Plot tab of the Eggbot Control extension, click the "Apply" button
  • Watch the plot

description.text:
Inspired by rlspell's http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17194, this drop-in has been modeled from scratch to fit all 8020 Series 10 extrusions. This nut can be dropped in and locked in place with a #10 screw.
Safety Disclaimer:
This is only for non-structural applications such as attaching panels or connecting self-supporting frames. Do not use for weight bearing structures (like shelving). Genuine 8020 hardware is readily available from distributors or on ebay (look for 8020inc) and I use it extensively.

Built with PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 with the following settings
Infill 100%
Shells 1
Layer 0.2mm
Extrude speed 80mm/sec
Travel speed 150mm/sec Use with either #10 self-tapping plastic screws or, as I did, drill out with a #25 drill bit and tap with a 10-24 tap. UPDATE: I ran a few of these using the new Taulman 645 nylon and they are awesome! Very strong and the threads will not strip out. Unfortunately you can't successfully run this material on your Rep2 without making a few...um...adjustments....

description.text:
I'm using the Robo3D R1 a couple of months now, and made 200+ prints so far working fine, until the bed temperature readout started to fail and showed 0 degrees.
While investigating this, I noticed Robo3D used a very crappy stiff grey cable, Totally not designed for bending all the time..
Also the cable was directly glued with silicone to the Glass bed.
I removed the cable and silicone.
Since I use the printer 100% of the time for postproduction I could not wait for a decent cableguide. So I had to fix it with the parts I had laying around at that moment.
First thing my eye fel on was the Y Idler block. Secured with 1 M4 screw.
I decided to use the unused idler hole on the other side to fix a cable guide, and make a cable mesh clamp secured on the stepper plate.
I also moved the Y Endstop, just to clear up the space for the cable mesh to run freely. For the bed wires I used silicone wire that is used in the RC scene,
That is made to flex arround. VIDEO of the modification: http://youtu.be/v9JPC_EkF2Y What do you need:
  • These printed parts.. prefer ABS
  • Cable Mesh arround 6-7mm dia.
  • Connector for connecting the bed wires (heater + thermistor) to the cable. (or just solder straight on).
    I Used Multiplex connectors, they can handle a max load of 35amps cont. and has some extra pins for the thermistor.
    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HVe5srJrDmo
  • Some 14awg silcone wire (got mine from hobbyking)
  • Some 22awg like wire for the thermistor

title: Oogoo Bonding Mesh with Laird Popkin's OpenSCAD Custom Mesh Generator

description.text: This is a test plate to test a 3d printed Oogoo bonding mesh. Oogoo cannot be glued to most plastics, so it is necessary to create a mechanical bond. The oogoo is applied into the mesh just after mixing with a spreader. After it cures, it is locked in place by the mesh. Bonding strength appears to be between 25psi to 50psi, but 100psi should be possible by adjusting mesh characteristics and oogoo mixture. The openSCAD custom mesh generator was created by Laird Popkin. The number of layers can be varied, the diameter of the tubes can be varied, the number of tubes per inch can be varied and the dimensions of length&width of the plate can be customized using the software. A link to Laird's software can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:518257

description.text:
This was inspired by jamesstaylor's Linear Bearing:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4311
Since I do not own Inventor, I could not open his files so that use some of his dimensions so I used my own dimensions and made some improvements of my own to the design. I first removed two of the 6 bearings that I seen other people use on Thingiverse for their linear bearings. I did this change because it is still stable so it will not wobble and because it uses less parts. Second, I made the linear bearings use 608 bearings because they are common and easy to obtain. Third, I made rod that the bearing can be used on a M8 so people can use it on 3D printers like RepRaps. Since I wanted to use it on M8 and have 608 bearings, I found that I did not have that much room to work with so I sank in the M8 nuts so that there was no interference. I decided not to remove the wall around the bolt because I did not want the bearings to hang and wobble. Post in the comments if you want me to modify it so it uses a different bearing type or different rod size. I also do not have a 3d printer so I could not test it out but send me pictures of it working and I will post it. Todo:
Put washer between bolt and bearing wall
Make it adjustable to account for rod tolerance error

Super simple, two part, low profile arc reactor made as an under the shirt Halloween costume.
Shows clearly through a black thermal and only gets better as it gets dark out.
Here is what you need:
1 battery pack (6V 4x AA)
24 LEDs
4 3x8mm bolts (glue or tape would also work)
1 strap (I cut a road bike tire in half for this)
Tony Stark style facial hair
A pocket for the battery pack

Some steps:
-It's a good idea to test the LEDs first to make sure they all work.
-Bend the leads up and press the LEDs into the front part.
Note: If it is a tight fit with some of them then lightly sanding the edge of the LED makes this much easier.
-Tie every two LEDs together in series so they each get 3V.
-Solder all the pairs together in parallel.
-Attach a wire long enough to reach your pocket.
-Attach the back part and add a strap.
Adding a switch would be nice although not necessary.
I wore it diagonally so it didn't move up/down.

I'm brand new to 3D printing, and this is my first attempt at modeling something and printing it, but it turned out surprisingly well so I figured I'd upload it since I couldn't find one someone else made on here.
When I first started using my Robo 3D with the spool that came with it, the spool kept falling off of where it should be on the spool holder, and created more tension for itself. In order to fix that, I made this ring to decrease the size of the hole in the center of the spool. So far it's working great.
The dimensions of this spool resizer are 2"x2"x1.2". I don't have any more spools, so I have no idea if this is the right size for any spools other than the 300g spool of test material that came with the Robo 3D Printer. It should also be noted that I added a piece of duct tape around the outside of the ring to increase traction and make it fit a little more snug. You could probably increase the diameter by a small bit and make it for more snugly, but I didn't want to have to reprint it and risk it being too big if adding a small bit of duct tape to a place you can't really see would fix it.

This is a device that allows your Makerbot (or other cnc machine) to draw/print/cut on cylindrical or spherical objects, in the manner of the EMS EggBot (http://egg-bot.com/). It works by connecting one of the machine's axises to a stepper motor, which then turns the workpiece.
The workpiece is held between two centers (several designs included) which are supported by two brackets: one holds the stepper motor, and the other holds a 608 bearing. The brackets are mounted on a dovetail way, which allows them to be positioned on the base, to accommodate different workpieces. After positioning, the brackets are clamped in place.

-Hardware-
  • Print the quantities of the parts listed in the parts list, along with your choice of centers. A heated build platform is not required, although it will help. You will need at least two centers; one for the motor ("5mm.stl" or "3mm.st", depending on your motor shaft diameter) and one for the bearing ("end__.stl").
  • Insert the bearing into the End Bracket.
  • Install the stepper motor into the motor bracket.
  • For each bracket: Insert a bolt into a clamp (clamp.stl), and push the bolt through the hole in the bracket. Add a washer, then a wheel (wheel.stl), then a nut. Tighten the nut so it stays on the shaft, then insert the bracket into the base, making sure that the clamp is lined up.
  • Connect the stepper motor to your machine. If you are using a Makerbot stepper driver, TURN OFF THE POWER BEFORE CONNECTING OR DISCONNECTING A MOTOR, or you will DESTROY THE DRIVER! If you are using a Makerbot, I recommend you connect the device to the Y axis.
    • -Software-
    Replicatorg does not handle angle coordinates, so you must establish a relationship between the linear distances in the gcode and the rotation of the motor. To do this, open the machines.xml file in your Replicatorg settings directory (on *nix systems, this is ~/.replicatorg). Duplicate the default definition for your machine, and give it a new name.
    Now you must choose the distance in the gcode you want to correspond with a full turn. I recommend 10cm (100mm). Take the number of steps per revolution of your stepper motor, divide it by your chosen distance in mm, and insert the resulting value into the scale property for the axis you connected the device to (axis scale="...."). If your stepper motor has 200 steps per revolution, and you choose 10cm as your distance, then you would put 2 into the scale property. -Usage-
    Loosen the clamps by turning the wheels and move the brackets far enough to insert your workpiece. Push the brackets into place and tighten the clamps. The cup centers may have trouble gripping the workpiece, because they are make of plastic (unlike the EggBot's rubber centers). Add a dab of hot glue if this is the case.

UPDATE 2/12/17. This part was used in the Ghostbusters Station 6 fan film. Check it out on youtube at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RHMUsQqLmRg UPDATE:28/11/16: Have been informed gun mount brackets to not align with holes. New brackets uploaded. Please let me know if there is a problem. UPDATE 25/08/2016 Added thrower clip UPDATE 02/11/2014:02:05 NoHoles version added which omits the bracket mounting holes by request.
A full size, 3D printable version of the Ghostbusters' proton pack
gun mount.
Based on Steffan Otto's drawing at:
http://www.gbfans.com/wiki/Stefan_Otto%27s_Prop_Plans
It is a hollow part like all my others to cut down on
plastic usage, but as the proton thrower (gun) needs to be mounted,
it uses an internal 2.5inch x 1.5inch piece of wood which is fastened to the motherboard, and the screws that support the gun bracket
fasten into this.
It also uses a stack of M4 washers in between the gun bracket and
the wood. This mechanically isolates the bracket from the mount,
ensuring the gun mount is secure and not reliant on the plastic for
strength.
Look at the second picture which shows the wood in red, and the
washers in black to get a better idea.
Print the gun bracket at 100% infill for maximum strength.
Print DrillCentres.pdf at 'actual size' to get the hole centres and
fasten onto motherboard with #4 self tapping screws.
There are two versions of this. Steffan's drawings show the gearbox with a buttress that fouls the gun mount by 3.2mm. I've uploaded
one copy of the gun mount which has a notch cut out to fix this.
If this is not clear, PM me.

Would you like a hands on tool for teaching students about buoyancy? This small 2in x 3in x 2in boat will help introduce the concept and prove the buoyancy equation. Play around with different infill percentages and see how many pennies you can add to the boat before it sinks! You can easily calculate the theoretical number of pennies it will be able to hold with the following steps:
For my print I used a 5% infill.
F_b=?V
F_b=(62.4 pcf)(2in3in2in)/?12?^3 ft
F_b=0.433 lbs
W_ABS=0.086 lbs (using a scale after printing)
W_pennies=F_b- W_ABS
W_pennies=0.433 lbs-0.086 lbs
W_pennies=0.347 lbs
N_pennies=W_pennies/(0.0055 lbs/penny)
N_pennies=(0.347 lbs)/(0.0055 lbs/penny)
N_pennies=63
My actual boat held 66 pennies before sinking (the surface tension of water and slight variability in penny weight accounted for the extra 3 pennies.)
You can also work backwards to calculate the mass/weight of the boat based on the number of pennies it held and compare it to the measured mass/weight using a scale.
This is a very accurate and direct application of buoyancy.

title: 55 Gallon Aquarium adjustable lightstand on a track

description.text:
Here is an aquarium light stand I printed. It was designed for the light to be on a track, that can move easily. Light fixture is sturdy but moves well enough that you can move it in the middle. I printed at .4mm with a .5m nozzle. The way the objects are orented on the print job makes the lines on the on the track lock in place with the pivotable support base. So when you move it you can feel them rubbing against each other but provides a nice click in place for a snug fit. I have also included the first design that doesn't have the track so if you want a stand but don't care for the track. Print the no_track.
Also, When I printed this for some reason one of the support columns was .5 mm larger. So print support1 and support2 if you want a snug fit.
The holder was designed to be 2" above the tank. I didn't include bigger ones but just push/pull the support stl's if you want a higher height. See the no_track picture. It technically looks better to me but Its just not as cool..

author: Jeremy8077

description.text: A little box with brackets for making a light source on, for example, a Prusa Boxed.

The box has 5 holes for 5mm High intensity LEDs and space for wiring them and whatever resistors the wiring needs.
The holes are angled up and down to spread the light better.
In my case I wired 2xLED in series with a 330ohm resistor, and another 3xLED in series with a 150ohm resistor. These two blocks were then fed in parallel from 12V. 12V |---LED---LED---LED---150---| GND 12V |-----LED-----LED-----330---| GND In the end I filled up the entire case with hot glue to make a completely solid part.

PRINT THAT THING created Maleficent horns for my lover lady, Amber. The horns print in 3 pieces and can easily be superglued together. An elastic trap runs through the base and then put on your head.
Feel free to comment if there is anything you'd like me to model/3D print for you on my youtube channel http://youtu.be/2hKeS2KBNA4 and if chosen will model, send you the first print, and upload the file for the rest of the world.

I printed HORN_BASES.slt & HORN_MIDDLES.stl with rafts but no supports, with .4mm layer height, 5% infill, and 2 shells.
I printed the HORN_TIPs.stl with raft & supports with .4mm layer height, 5% infill, and 2 shells.
Feel free to try other settings for strength. Please let me know if you have any questions.
Once printed, we superglued the parts together and added an elastic strap through the BASE bar and put it on the head.

title: 2 in 1 woodworking marking gauge for wood and metal with IKEA pencil and nail

description.text:
I designed a 2 in 1 woodwokring marking gauge. It uses an IKEA pencil (the ones you geht for free at the store) or a nail to mark parallel lines to an edge onto a surface.
Its an often used tool at woodworking.
You can also use any other normal pencil with similar size.
You can choose between the nail or the pencil.
The part wich is not needed at that moment can be stored in the rod.
In german, this tool is named Steichmaß. You need:
  • the 3d-printed parts
  • 2x M3 screws and nuts
  • 1x M5 screw and nut
  • 1x small nail (the hole at the rod has a diameter of 1,3mm but you can drill it bigger if you need to)
  • 1x IKEA pencil

description.text:
I needed a set of legs for my Printrbot Simple Metal, but none of the ones I could find would raise it up high enough for all the wiring underneath, and the ones that I tried fell off whenever I moved it around even the slightest. So I designed my own!
I designed them so they are easily printable, and fit within the print area of my Printrbot. No support material should be necessary to successfully print them. The front legs are a little lose and could probably use a little reduction in the channel width, but they keep it from moving around so I didn't feel like re-designing and reprinting. The rear legs are pretty tight and take some wiggling, but should fit well. The "feet" are 20mm x 20mm, which is big enough for some little rubber feet I picked up from my local hardware store, to help reduce vibrations.

I recommend printing them "feet up", and at a 45 degree angle across the Z axis. At least that's how I got my best print.   
No support material should be necessary - they were designed to be easily printable.  
The ones pictured in the gallery were printed at .2mm resolution.

title: Vice Jaws for holding a Victorinox Cadet 84mm Swiss Army Knife

description.text:
A set of custom vise jaws for holding an 84mm Victorinox Cadet swiss army knife.  
This is useful if you are building a custom 84mm alox knife.  It allows you to securely hold the knife for drilling out the rivets, without damaging the scales.  
Just remove the keyring and the knife should snap into place.  Then clamp in your favorite vise with parallels.

I printed it in ABS, 100% infill.  You probably want 100% infill so that it doesn't collapse under the pressure of the vise. (Though you still don't want to crank down too much on these)  
I used four corner mouse-ears to help it stay flat to the bed.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:368375 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=368375

A klein bottle with wireframe style so the whole surface can be seen. With a solid surface the bottle looks not so exciting and the meaning is difficult to understand. So I made this version.
It prints without support, but isn't very easy to print, because it needs a precise calibration and good adhesion on the bed.
Edit: I tested it now with 0.3mm layers and it printed successfully (yellow image).

I printed it with 0.15mm layer, 0.5mm nozzle, no support and no infill. For better adhesion my printing bed is covered by Kapton tape. It took 2h and consumed 2m of my 3mm filament (15,5cm³).
(Same settings with 0.3mm layers took 50min and printed successful, too)
As there are bridges everywhere, you should calibrate your bridging in before.
Because the contact surface is very small, it's likely to move while printing, ruining the print. I've made a version with predefined brim, which can be more easily removed, because it doesn't fill the holes of the model. The model without brim is there too if you want to manage the brim on yourself.

comments.text: Since I posted the comment I talked to a friend who has wrestled with understanding and visualizing 4D representations in 3D space for many decades.  (His latest endeavor is to understand Clifford algebra which when applied in 5D space apparently is useful for computer graphics where there is handling of perspectives.  (I can't say that I really understand it.))    He was doubtful that the extension of a Moibus strip to make a 3D object does indeed "have a hole" through the surface, so maybe the print is correct as it stands.  To me, for this to be called a "bottle" it should have a hole, but maybe some mathematicians disagree.  Such details aside, the print is really very nice, and people I show it to are intrigued and delighted by it.

I wanted to make an adjustable filament spool caddy, since my first two spools don't match spans. I made a simple flange for holding a common 608zz radial skate bearing in line with an OpenBeam or other t-slot extrusion. This through-bolt design uses inexpensive hardware, and should be easily printed four-at-a-time on any filament printer. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DvV1EzdiDxo

(1) Print up to four of this part.
(2) Attach the parts to OpenBeam extrusion framework as shown in the photos, flanges to the outside.
(3) I recommend a 5/16" or M8 bolt, a matching nut, and three washers with similar inner diameter.
(4) Bolt, washer, bearing, washer, this plastic part, washer, nut. The smoother side of a washer should face toward a bearing or nut.
(5) Rest your filament spool on top of the washers.
(6) Attach rubber sticky feet or Sugru pads to avoid sliding on the table top.

comments.text: I like your design - and I've built one like it.  The only real complaint I have is that as the spools get empty, they get light, and they end up getting pulled off of the caddy.

title: Remix - GoPro Gimbal Parts - Camera Arm

description.text:
On my gimbal, I placed the arm on the other side of the camera so that I had access to a video link. The standard part and configuration does not allow for this. I also cut in an inset to the bottom for the board placement.
I'm having issues, as my gimbal constantly seems to be trying to acquire center balance, but cant, and vibrates a lot. When I was using the stock metal parts, even after I've reversed the sides, I had it working. My assumption is this has something to do with the change in weight of the mount.
I've asked the original creator if he ran into this issue and how to fix. If anyone else out there has any ideas, please comment and let me know. Otherwise, I'll post a fix when I figure it out in case anyone else runs into same issue.

comments.text: Your vibration is indeed because of the weight change and balance issues.  If you can balance the gimbal manually with weights first then you may not need to resort to more changes but any other change will require software to tune to the gimbal.
comments.author: djtaylor

Death Gun from Sword Art Online(Gun Gale Online) I just set up a shop on Shapeways. This mask is available for sale.
https://www.shapeways.com/shops/ferreusveritas

This design has been scaled by 120% of it's previous size to fit the average adult sized head.
Warped the back edges of the mask out a little for more comfort. Added a buckle hole to the top of the mask. Files are better separated with the ready-to-print mask still included. Ready to print file should fit snugly on Makerbot Replicator 2.
Whole mask file included for those who would like to cut for printing in a different way.
Designed from official reference art in Blender and Inkscape.  Artistic license was employed to adapt it from anime art to fit a real human head.

Print:
  • Bottom and Top(or whole mask)
  • 2X vent
  • 2X lens retainer
  • 4X lens spacer
  • 5X buckle
  • 5X buckle bushing
    • Print pieces, cut off helper discs, superglue halves together. Ready-to-print mask file is designed to be printed without supports. A lens file was added but is not meant to be printed(unless you can print a clear lens). It's just for reference. Lens spacers are meant to hold 2 35mm lenses together with a colored acetate sandwiched between them. Mask takes:
  • 3 X #8x1/4 Machine Screws for front(optional, thread directly into plastic)
  • 5 X #10x1/4 Machine Screws for buckles(optional for buckle attachments)
  • Elastic and/or velcro for fastening.
  • Optional glass lenses 35mmx1mm glass circles for the goggles
  • 2 x #4x1/4 sheet metal screws for lens retainers.
    • I printed the mask in PLA. Glued together, bondo, sanded, flat black primer, acrylic dry brush paint, sealed with spray-able gloss modge podge.
    Glue vents on after bondo and sanding. Pro Tip:
    If using PLA the glued mask can be reshaped to fit if held over a steam bath for a minute or so.

comments.text: Hello, I was curious on what you did for the actual lenses on the mask. Did you just cut the glass and film interlayer yourself, or where you able to get them from somewhere? I've been searching online for a few days now and have come up with nothing and I have no knowledge of glass working, so this is driving me crazy.
comments.author: infiniteOdyssey

comments.text:
I got the glass circles from hobby lobby. It was part of some jewelry kit that came with 4 glass circles and 2 circular metal frames for placing a photo between the glass layers and wearing it like a pendant. The problem is that the sizes of the glass circles from that kit was for the old mask design which was pretty much universally accepted that it was way too small. I made the model larger to fit an "adult sized" head and now even those glass circles are too small(if you can even find them anymore). I used to have a link in the thing details but it no longer applies.
If you want the quickest path to a solution then just get some thin plexiglass from your local hardware store and cut it into a circle.
I know it sucks but there's probably no affordable way around the problem. Cutting small glass circles is a challenge in itself. Plus, I don't know what you intend to do with the mask but thin layers of frail glass right in front of your eyeballs might be a bad idea.
comments.author: infiniteOdyssey

comments.text: As far as having people print things out for you. I can't speak for everyone but It's seldom worth their time.  Any common FDM printer will take 10 hours+ to print out the mask even in medium quality(0.2mm layers).  It's either going to be expensive for you to make it worth their while or it's going to be a big favor on their part.  Simply put, if a person could have afford a decent printer to begin with then they probably make more money spending their time doing things other than printing toys and costumes.  This is why print requests typically are ignored.  If you need something printed and don't want to rely on members of the community then shapeways is a good, reliable, albeit expensive option.  I look forward to seeing your future creations. :)
comments.author: WASALU

comments.text:
I'm probably going to be the only one who sees this question so you might want to ask it elsewhere or do some research..
I used a makerbot replicator 2 to print the mask. For the rep2 once I got all the bugs worked out(extruder upgrade, overhead filament rack, aluminum build plate, aluminum reinforcing arms, naptha and achohol to clean build plate, and mineral oil to lubricate filament) it's a great printer that never fails. Unfortunately that model is discontinued. Now makerbot has several overpriced printers with additional features that serve little purpose but to drive up the cost. There's many 3d printers out there. Look around and pay attention to user ratings and software options.

comments.text: Could you give me some more information on your printer setup, are you using screw threads on axis's? If so what sizes and why please?
comments.author: dantyas

comments.text: These a pretty straight forward to print.  25% infill, 3 outer shell.  There is no threads.  You will need 5 mm screws to attach the plastic parts to the aluminium extrusions.
comments.author: dantyas

comments.text: Sorry I meant your printer in general. It apppeaes you're using screw thread drives for your x y axis movement. This interested me since most would use belt drive.
comments.author: ctheroux

comments.text: oups!!!  I am using 10 starts lead screws for the x and y axis.  They are 10 mm in diameter with a 25 mm pitch. Why? I wanted to try lead screws when I designed this printer.  I thought it would lower the vibration that make sometimes artifacts (small waves) on printed parts.  I reduced it but did not eliminated it.  These were high-end lead screws from Trinity Labs.  They closed a few years ago.  The Z uses cheap Chinese 8 mm lead screws.  One draw back is that the motor needs to run a bit (15%) slower (17HS8401) since the anti-backlash nut is stiffer.
comments.author: dantyas

title: 30A Power Supply Case with Power Panel, Banana Plugs and Switch

description.text: I wanted a high amperage power supply with an ammeter.  You can pickup a 30A supply for fairly cheap.  See instructions for sources.

Almost everything came from amazon with the exception of the power switch which came from Radio Shack. However any switch that mounts in a 20mm hole will work just fine.
Shopping List:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/3PSRJKEC7RZ2Y/ref=cm_wl_rlist_go_o? Power Switch:
http://www.radioshack.com/spst-16a-125v-illuminated-round-rocker-switch-with-red-led/2750020.html#q=round+switch&start=5 Print with support with the panel face down. You will also need 3 M4x6mm bolts to attach the panel to the power supply. I had to cut down the shunt for it to fit in the box. I removed all but a couple of millimeters from the mounting area of the shunt. Leaving one of the mounting holes but removing the large bolts entirely.

author: jwellman

description.text:
This model is available from honda at the following website: http://www.honda-3d.com/
I did not design or create this. I do not own any part of it. I recently printed this car and I had some trouble with it so I decided to post it here for better exposure and with some tips to print it. See instructions for details

I printed this on a makerbot 2 with 10% infill, raft and supports. I set the detail at 0.15 but the amount of detail is up to you. The main trouble I had was with the model being not level when imported into makerware. The back wheels were slightly raised which caused the printer to print in the air which didnt work. To solve this I had to go into the rotation submenu and I had to click lay flat which solved the problem.

title: StarWars EpVII A New Helmet.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Yes typing error.. will fix if anyone notices it.
Is this the new helmet? I don't know, but I hope so, it looks cool.
A user by the name of Smookcmb made a low res mesh.. he was pretty close.. it can be found here..
http://www.mintinbox.net/Actus/14-08/2208stormVII_pepakura
I took his mesh, converted it to an obj and then put it into zbrush to work out the details. I tried it in Blender but the Zbrush result looks better.
Now if we compare it to the leaked photo, the visor in the photo extends all the way around the top of the nose, there are no eye sockets like the traditional, so I went around those, of course added a gabillion polygons to it to smooth it over (second pic shows original mesh) and made a base and hole for it, which is optional.
Supports are required..
This is a work in progress as the helmet might change... and I need to remove the small lip that's above the eyes if I want it closer to the leaked photo.
***Full size mask?
Not yet, let's wait and see some more leaks before we go printing a full size one! that may have just been a prototype or test, so let's not jump the gun too much.

title: Fido U2F Plug-Up security key case

description.text: This is a case for the Fido U2F Plug-Up Security Key.  I was concerned about my Security Key getting damaged on my keyring, so I created this case to go around it.  This is designed to print in one pass of a 0.4mm nozzle and allow a small amount of shrinkage of the plastic.  I also drilled the hole a bit larger on the Security Key itself so that it would fit on my keyring.  I use a bit of paracord for my keyring.

I printed this on my FlashForge Creator.  I used MakerWare and imported the .stl file.  I told it to move the object to the build platform.  Then I switched the filament to the left side and changed the default ABS to PLA.  I also turned off the heated build plate.  This printed just fine in low quality mode - 0.3mm layer thickness.  The scad file is available if you have different settings such as nozzle thickness or your plastic shrinks differently.  Maybe you used a different diameter hole when you drilled out your Security Key :).

title: Universal Connector

description.text:
I designed this item to make easy connections and simple structures out of 3/4 inch wood rod. Think of it as an oversized tinkertoy to build whatever comes to your imagination. I have, however, only printed 1 so far and was very pleased with my results. Make sure your belts on your printer are tight. I did not, and I had a mid shift print so it ended up a little to one side. 
I will make more connectors to add to its features. My end goal is to make enough connectors to make outside structures to support some of my smaller solar panels.
Print. Build. Enjoy :)

title: AstroPrint Astrobox top for PCDuino v2 pin access
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
06-19-2015 slight update to enlarge the SPI (and other) pins for boards that use the spi (like the arduino touch lcd shields).   
The AstroPrint Astrobox PCDuino v2 - 3D Print Controller has one thing going for it the PCduino3s does not. Arduino UNO compatible pins!  It has Arduino UNO pins as well as Extra 8 GPIO pins that can be accessed from the Lubuntu OS that is currently running your 3d print server.   
You just need to be able to plug in your UNO Shields or access the individual pins. That's where this case cover comes in. Just remove the original AstroPrint Astrobox PCDuino v2 cover and use this one instead for full access to all the pins. (Running the arduino IDE or other languages to control them are up to you!)

description.text:
The airbrush compressor I was sold was shipped with an airbrush support, but this one was designed for airbrush with paint container located on top of the airbrush.
I designed this airbrush support for those like me who have an airbrush with the pain container located on the right.
I added a "sticker" in order not to be bothered with separation from the bed during print.
Printed very well in 0.3mm, with the addition of support 45Deg and 4mm for Pattern spacing, honeycomb pattern.
Hope this will help a few Airbrush lovers.

title: Taco Holder - Rolls over for easy filling / Flat base holds Taco upright when served

description.text:
If you prefer traditional shaped Taco's (not the wide flat bottomed shells) this is for you...
The Taco holder supports Taco Shells during filling and also on your plate. This holder lets you roll your Taco over for ease of filling then hold it upright so the filling doesn't fall out when it's served and being eaten.
The Taco Holder has designed in support that should be easy to remove. Place your Taco Shell in the slot running through the holder (not lengthwise) as this lets you roll the Taco Shell sideways for easy filling but it shouldn't fall over. The shape makes it 'self righting' so it will return to the upright position to keep the filling inside.
Once filled invert the holder and place lengthwise so its flat base will keep your Taco upright when served and while being eaten.
Refer to instructions and images.

Print with 4 shells and 35% plus infill to make it strong but also flexible. The Taco Holder prints upside down with designed in support that should be very easy to snap away. Use Raft but do not turn Support on.
